questions.question: What is the primary reason Sydney Brenner chose C. elegans as a model organism?

answers.ans: Its simplicity and power for genetic studies.
Its ability to survive in extreme environments.
Its large size and complex anatomy.

questions.question: What is the typical magnification used to observe C. elegans with a dissecting microscope?
How many neurons are present in the adult hermaphrodite C. elegans?
What is the frequency of male C. elegans arising in a population?
What is the length of the C. elegans life cycle at 25°C from egg to egg-laying adult?
What is the primary food source for C. elegans in laboratory conditions?
What is the function of the dauer larva stage in C. elegans?

answers.ans: It allows survival during unfavorable conditions.
It is the primary reproductive stage.
It is a stage for rapid growth.
It is a stage for mating.

questions.question: What is the significance of the invariant number of somatic cells in C. elegans?

answers.ans: It allows researchers to track cell lineage from fertilization to adulthood.
It allows for a diverse range of phenotypes.

questions.question: What is the primary advantage of C. elegans being a self-fertilizing hermaphrodite?

answers.ans: A single animal can populate a plate.

questions.question: How many somatic cells are present in a newly hatched C. elegans larva?
What is the primary method used to visualize individual cells in C. elegans?
What is the role of the spermatheca in C. elegans hermaphrodites?
How long can C. elegans survive in stasis without food?
What is the primary reason C. elegans is used in genetic studies?

answers.ans: Its ability to self-fertilize simplifies genetic analysis.
Its large genome allows for complex studies.

questions.question: What is the purpose of using fluorescent proteins in C. elegans research?

answers.ans: To tag proteins or subcellular compartments for visualization.
To increase the organism's growth rate.
To enhance the organism's resistance to stress.
To alter the organism's genetic code.

questions.question: What is the primary advantage of C. elegans' transparency?

answers.ans: It allows visualization of individual cells and subcellular details.
It increases the organism's resistance to UV light.
It enhances the organism's reproductive capabilities.

questions.question: What is the significance of the C. elegans genome being fully sequenced?

answers.ans: It facilitates forward and reverse genetics studies.
It enhances the organism's resistance to disease.

questions.question: What is the role of the dauer larva cuticle in C. elegans?

answers.ans: It provides enhanced resistance to environmental stresses.

questions.question: What is the primary reason for using C. elegans in developmental biology studies?

answers.ans: Its invariant cell lineage allows for precise tracking of cell fate.
Its large size and complex anatomy.

questions.question: What is the systematic gene identification for the third predicted gene on cosmid ZK154?
How is a homozygous allele represented in C. elegans nomenclature?
What does the nomenclature "mnDp30" indicate in C. elegans genetics?
In C. elegans, what does the term "Mec" refer to?
What type of mutation is indicated by the nomenclature "nDf6"?
What is the significance of the allele designation "e1506/1" in C. elegans?
Which laboratory is associated with the allele designation "muIs35"?
What does the term "mec-7p::gfp" represent in C. elegans genetic nomenclature?

answers.ans: GFP transcriptional fusion using only the promoter of the gene
GFP translational fusion in the coding sequence of the gene

questions.question: What does the "Ex" label in "evEx1" signify in C. elegans genetics?
What is the primary mutagenic effect of ethane methylsulfonate (EMS) in C. elegans?

answers.ans: GC-to-AT transition mutations and small deletions

questions.question: What is the average number of mutations per strain in the "million mutation project"?
How many unique mutations were identified in the "million mutation project"?
What is the average number of times each gene has been mutated in the "million mutation project"?
What is the primary purpose of using RNA interference (RNAi) in C. elegans research?
What is the advantage of C. elegans transparency in biological studies?

answers.ans: Allows examination of development and changes at the level of a single, identified cell

questions.question: What does the "GRASP" technique in C. elegans research involve?

answers.ans: Mapping of cell–cell and synaptic contacts by expressing complementary fragments of GFP
RNA interference to reduce gene activity

questions.question: What is the role of the cuticle in C. elegans?

answers.ans: Determines body shape and provides anchoring points for muscle contraction

questions.question: What phenotype results from mutations in collagen genes affecting C. elegans cuticle?
What is the function of the epidermis in C. elegans?

answers.ans: Acts as a model for the innate immune response and repair after physical wounds
Provides structural support for internal organs

questions.question: What is the primary advantage of using microfluidic devices in C. elegans research?

answers.ans: Allows application of compounds while monitoring fluorescent readout of gene regulation

questions.question: What is the unique structural feature of C. elegans somatic muscles compared to vertebrate muscles?

answers.ans: They are obliquely striated and mononucleate.
They are longitudinally striated and multinucleate.
They are circularly striated and binucleate.
They are radially striated and polynucleate.

questions.question: How do C. elegans muscle cells receive synaptic input from motor neurons?

answers.ans: Muscle cells send extensions to the ventral and dorsal cord to receive synapses.
Motor neurons project axons directly onto muscle cells.
Muscle cells receive synapses through direct contact with motor neuron cell bodies.
Synaptic input is received through chemical diffusion from nearby neurons.

questions.question: What is the primary neurotransmitter system absent in C. elegans neurons that is typically present in vertebrates?
What is the function of the pharyngeal bulbs in C. elegans?
What is the primary form of synaptic connection in C. elegans neurons?
Which neurotransmitters are used by C. elegans neurons?

answers.ans: Acetylcholine, glutamate, GABA, dopamine, and serotonin.

questions.question: What is the role of the TRA-1 transcription factor in C. elegans?
How does C. elegans achieve dosage compensation between sexes?

answers.ans: By downregulating X-linked gene expression by 50% in hermaphrodites.
By upregulating autosomal gene expression in males.
By duplicating the X chromosome in males.
By silencing one X chromosome in hermaphrodites.

questions.question: What is the primary dispersal form of C. elegans in the wild?
What is the significance of the SL1 and SL2 leader sequences in C. elegans mRNA?

answers.ans: They aid in translational initiation and identify the 5' end of mRNAs.
They are involved in mRNA splicing.

questions.question: What is the average gene size in C. elegans, and what primarily contributes to this size?

answers.ans: 3 kb, due to very small introns.
10 kb, due to extensive promoter regions.
1 kb, due to lack of introns.

questions.question: What is the primary ecological habitat of C. elegans in the wild?

answers.ans: Organic-rich garden soils, compost, and rotting fruit.

questions.question: What is the role of gap junctions in C. elegans neurons?

answers.ans: They allow direct electrical communication between neurons.
They provide structural support to neurons.

questions.question: What is the primary method of gene regulation studied in C. elegans?

answers.ans: Transcription, translation, chromatin remodeling, and post-transcriptional modifications.

questions.question: How do C. elegans neurons differ from vertebrate neurons in synapse formation?

answers.ans: They do not send terminal branches with boutons to make synapses.
They form synapses exclusively through terminal boutons.
They rely solely on chemical diffusion for synapse formation.
They form synapses only at the cell body.

questions.question: What is the primary function of the male tail in C. elegans?

answers.ans: It is involved in mating and contains 18 projections of neurons and support cells.

questions.question: What is the significance of the C. elegans genome being sequenced?

answers.ans: It was the first multicellular eukaryotic organism to have its genome sequenced.
It was the first prokaryotic organism to have its genome sequenced.
It was the largest genome ever sequenced.
It was the first organism to have its mitochondrial genome sequenced.

questions.question: What is the primary reason for the absence of sodium-dependent action potentials in C. elegans neurons?

answers.ans: Very high membrane resistance makes action potentials unnecessary.

questions.question: What is the role of the Notch, EGF, and Wnt pathways in C. elegans?

answers.ans: They coordinate the spatiotemporal development of the vulva.

questions.question: What was the first complete wiring diagram of a nervous system published?
Which year was the first axon guidance gene discovered?
In which year was the role of Notch signaling in embryonic blastomeres identified?
When were par genes, affecting asymmetric distribution in embryos, discovered?
What year marks the identification of the first LIM and POU homeodomain transcription factors?
When was the first description of RAS signaling function in metazoan development made?
In which year was the role of insulin pathway genes in regulating lifespan demonstrated?
When was the first microRNA (lin-4) and its mRNA target (lin-14) described?
What year marks the introduction of GFP as a biological marker?
When was the first metazoan genome sequenced?
In which year was RNA interference (RNAi) discovered?
When was the conservation and ubiquity of miRNAs first reported?
What year marks the development of genome-wide RNAi screening?
When was the first cytoplasmic polyA polymerase (gld-2) discovered?
In which year was the first full-genome RNAi profiling of early embryogenesis conducted?
When was the first use of channelrhodopsin optogenetics in an intact animal?
What year marks the discovery of the first nematode viruses?
Which year did the first demonstration of specific olfactory receptor/ligand pair occur?
When was the first description of nonsense-mediated decay genes made?
What year marks the first identification of genes for conserved synaptic functions?
Which gene in C. elegans is required for the generation of the pharyngeal primordium?
What is the role of the unc-18 gene in C. elegans?

answers.ans: Encodes a protein expressed in motor neurons
Encodes a protein for synaptic vesicle fusion

questions.question: Which gene is associated with the regulation of longevity and diapause in C. elegans?
What is the function of the ced-9 gene in C. elegans?

answers.ans: Encodes a functional homolog of the mammalian proto-oncogene bcl-2
Encodes a protein for motor neuron function

questions.question: Which gene in C. elegans encodes a ras protein involved in vulval induction?
What is the primary focus of the study by Hedgecock, E. M., and J. G. White in 1985?
Which gene is required for synaptic vesicle fusion in C. elegans?
What is the significance of the mec-7 gene in C. elegans?

answers.ans: Required for the production of 15-protofilament microtubules
Encodes a protein for motor neuron function

questions.question: Which gene in C. elegans is homologous to a set of mammalian proteins that includes epidermal growth factor?
What is the role of the lin-4 gene in C. elegans?

answers.ans: Encodes small RNAs with antisense complementarity to lin-14
Encodes a protein for motor neuron function

questions.question: Which gene in C. elegans is involved in the inheritance of RNA interference?
What is the function of the unc-54 gene in C. elegans?

answers.ans: Encodes a protein for synaptic vesicle fusion

questions.question: Which gene in C. elegans specifies cell fates during vulval induction?
What is the role of the lin-12 locus in C. elegans?

answers.ans: Encodes a protein for motor neuron function

questions.question: Which gene in C. elegans is required for the differentiation of touch receptor neurons?
What is the function of the ced-3 gene in C. elegans?

answers.ans: Encodes a protein similar to mammalian interleukin-1 beta-converting enzyme
Encodes a protein for synaptic vesicle fusion

questions.question: Which gene in C. elegans is associated with the regulation of asymmetric cell division?
What is the role of the pha-4 gene in C. elegans?

answers.ans: Required to generate the pharyngeal primordium
Encodes a protein for motor neuron function

questions.question: Which gene in C. elegans is involved in the regulation of hermaphrodite fertility?
What is the function of the daf-2 gene in C. elegans?

answers.ans: Encodes a protein for synaptic vesicle fusion
